trustfund:
TF025430-PHRD-ECONOMIC ADJUSTMENT CREDIT,TF022383-PARTNERSHIP ON SUSTAINABLE
            STRATEGIES FOR GIRLS' EDUCATION,TF022376-SUSTAINABLE STRATEGIES FOR
            GIRL'S EDUCATION - UNICEF,TF021779-APDF - AFDB CONTRIBUTIONS,TF021209-MULTI-AGENCY PARTNERSHIP ON
            GIRLS EDUCATION,TF023405-ECONOMIC RECOVERY CREDIT,TF023335-ECONOMIC RECOVERY CREDIT TO MOZAMBIQUE,TF024252-ECONOMIC RECOVERY CREDIT GRANT 1994

abstracts.cdata!:
The Economic Recovery Credit Project
            will support Mozambique's Economic and Social
            Rehabilitation Program (ESRP). The objects of the credit are
            to enhance private sector-based growth, redeploy budgetary
            expenditures towards key social sectors and small holder
            agriculture and provide support for drought-relief. The
            credit has four main components. First, it will improve
            foreign exchange allocation and export incentives by
            developing a consolidated market for foreign exchange,
            liberalizing prices of manufactured products and reforming
            agricultural marketing. Second, it will strengthen the role
            of the Central Bank, improve access to credit by the private
            sector and develop commercial banking services. Third, the
            credit will accelerate the restructuring and privatization
            of the state enterprise sector and establish a transparent
            system for privatization. Fourth, the credit will reorient
            budgetary expenditures to protect a set of high-priority
            activities in primary health, primary and secondary
            education, smallholders in agriculture, and provide support
            for the implementation of limited targeted direct income
            transfers to poor households. The proceeds of the credit
            will be used by Mozambique to support the enlargement of the
            secondary market and finance technical assistance to
            strengthen the government's capacity to extend the
            privatization process to large enterprises and reform the
            banking sector.
